data.title: Street Girl (1929)
data.meta_description: A homeless and destitute violinist joins a combo to bring it success, but has problems with her love life.
data.text:
‚ÄúTell us more about your hard struggles, will ya?‚Äù

Skirt in Band

Jack Oakie blowing on the woodwind, Ned Sparks on the sax: ‚ÄúLovable and Sweet‚Äù. Small joys.

A saccharine story about ‚Äúthe troupe.‚Äù A real ‚Äúguys rule‚Äù kind of early talking picture, as John Harron brings hungry girl Betty Compson back to the musical boys club apartment for a sandwich and Ned Sparks walks out on a towel. Compson is doing a broken English accent from the fictional Kingdom of Aregon, and its prince, Ivan Lebedeff, which usually doesn‚Äôt work for me, but is actually super adorable.

Loses some of the comedic fun of the first quarter during the jealous middle section, but that sequin and flesh colored outfit‚Ä¶

Watched as part of a new experiment --- New Letterboxd list here has more details (if interested)

It is said that this is the first film made by RKO Radio Pictures (but released after the 2nd made picture). It is interesting to watch this just because of that (and to see Jack Oakie or Ned Sparks --- if you are a fan of one or both of them).

The biggest fault of this lies with its co-star -- John Harron. He is supposed to be the Gable, the Powell (Dick or William) or the Francis Lederer or Ricardo Cortez of this picture, but unlike all those Harron seems to have no charisma (and, or so it appears, got into the‚Ä¶

üé∂Broken Up Tune....You're Doing itüé∂

This song's melody has stuck in my head since the first time I ever heard it. Today, after paying more attention to the musical finale, I can associate some lyrics with the melody. I got a real kick out of a scene late in the movie. The entertainment group had just inked a deal to perform for $3000 a week. The next morning, the accordion player, Jack Oakie? and Guy Buccola are rehearsing some bit. Ned Sparks grumpily comes down the stairs to watch this Buccola guy do his shtick. He's invented some new form of dance and is showing off to the boys.... 'wait until they get a load of this! If this don't‚Ä¶
